questions.question: How to use the print submission system
questions.answer: Yes. Upload the files you want to merge. Choose the library tab; select the appropriate files; and press the merge icon. You can also add blank pages and/or change the order of the files.

questions.question: My job has more than one file. Can I merge them before I send them?
questions.answer: Yes. Upload the files you want to merge. Choose the library tab; select the appropriate files; and press the merge icon. You can also add blank pages and/or change the order of the files.

questions.question: Can I submit more than one file per request?
questions.answer: Please ensure that you only place one print order per job request.  If you have the duplicate  print instructions for each job i.e. A1 matt poster for a student hand in, you can send a zipped file through the Print Submission system.  The system will not be able to provide a quote at this stage.

questions.question: How do I track a job?
questions.answer: To track the order, select the 'Orders' option in the print submission system.

questions.question: How should I supply files?
questions.answer: Please supply a PDF file (at least 300 dpi, or dots per inch) for printing.

questions.question: Who can apply for University of Bristol international undergraduate scholarships, and which courses are eligible?
questions.answer: To be eligible for the University's undergraduate scholarships, you must:

questions.question: Do I need to have applied for a course at the University of Bristol before I apply for the University of Bristol international undergraduate scholarships?
questions.answer: Yes. You need to have already applied to study at the University of Bristol starting in 2025 to apply for the University of Bristol international undergraduate scholarships.

questions.question: Do I need to have an offer to study at the University of Bristol to be able to apply for the University of Bristol international undergraduate scholarships?
questions.answer: No. As long as you meet the eligibility requirements and you have submitted an application to study at the University of Bristol, you can apply for the University of Bristol international undergraduate scholarships, even if you have not yet received an offer to study.

questions.question: I am applying for more than one course at the University of Bristol. How should I complete the international scholarships application form?
questions.answer: If you have applied to study more than one course at the University of Bristol, select the course you would most like to be considered for.

questions.question: What documents do I need to apply for the University of Bristol international undergraduate scholarships?
questions.answer: You do not need to submit any documentation when applying for the University of Bristol international undergraduate scholarships.

questions.question: What is a UCAS ID, student ID or Kaplan ID?
questions.answer: UCAS ID (UCAS Personal ID): This is the number given to you in your welcome email when you registered with UCAS. If you cannot remember what your UCAS ID is, you can search for it on the UCAS Track website .

questions.question: Is there an age restriction for applying for the University of Bristol international undergraduate scholarships?
questions.answer: No. There is no age restriction for students applying for the University of Bristol international undergraduate scholarships.

questions.question: Am I eligible for a University of Bristol international undergraduate scholarship if I select Bristol as my insurance choice in UCAS?
questions.answer: You do not need to decide your firm and insurance choices in UCAS at the point of submitting a University of Bristol international undergraduate scholarship application.

questions.question: If I have applied for more than one University scholarship, can I still I apply for the University of Bristol international undergraduate scholarships?
questions.answer: By completing the application form, you will be considered for all scholarships and bursaries that you are eligible for.

questions.question: Do the University of Bristol international undergraduate scholarships cover living expenses or air fare?
questions.answer: All University of Bristol international undergraduate scholarships are towards tuition fees only and will not cover any living expenses, air fares or other expenses.

questions.question: Do I need to meet any additional English language requirements to be able to apply for the University of Bristol international undergraduate scholarships?
questions.answer: No. You will not need to meet any additional English language requirements to apply for the University of Bristol international undergraduate scholarships.

questions.question: Will I receive individual feedback on my application if I am unsuccessful?
questions.answer: No. Unfortunately, due to the large number of applications we receive, we cannot provide individual feedback to applicants.

questions.question: Will a list of successful applicants be published on the University's website?
questions.answer: No. We contact all applicants directly by email and we do not publish the total number of allocated awards.

questions.question: Can the University give me an early decision?
questions.answer: No. The University must follow the correct procedure to make sure that all applicants are considered fairly.

questions.question: -Why is this study important?-
questions.answer: CFS/ME is common.  At least 1% of teenagers miss a day a week of school because of CFS/ME. Children and young people with CFS/ME suffer because they cannot do what they want to do. They miss large amounts of school, social activities and sport. We know that mothers often have to reduce or stop work (and we assume this is likely to be true for all care givers). The National Institute of Health and Clinical Excellence (NICE) says that children with CFS/ME should be able to access specialist care and treatment. Specialist treatment is effective but most children in the UK do not have a local specialist service and therefore cannot access treatment.

questions.question: What are the aims of the research project?
questions.answer: Our research aims to help understand factors associated with contact with the criminal justice system and its impact on social and health-related outcomes, with the following specific aims that will use both Children of the 90s and linked data in order to:

questions.question: Where will data be linked from the Children of the 90s?
questions.answer: For those participants who have given permission to participate in data linkage, we will link to the Avon and Somerset Constabulary data on conviction, caution and recorded criminal behaviour.

questions.question: What is the process for linking data and what information will be used?
questions.answer: Avon and Somerset Constabulary will provide Children of the 90s with the individual data but will not know the identity of any Children of the 90s participant or be able to access individual data about the study or participants. Children of the 90s will not share any personal information such as name, address or date of birth with Avon and Somerset Constabulary. The following process will be carried out to link CO90s data to the data sources described above:

questions.question: Where are my linked records stored?
questions.answer: The University of Bristol will download and store the data onto the Children of the 90s’ Data Linkage team’s secure ‘encapsulated virtual machine’ (eVM) which is a purpose-built secure research server at the University of Bristol. The Children of the 90’s data linkage team and their eVM are certified as meeting the ISO 27001 Information Security standard, the ‘gold standard’ for information security. Within the Children of the 90s data linkage team eVM there are separate working areas for Children of the 90s data linkage team Data Managers and for research users. Research users are only able to access the minimum de-identified data needed for their project.

questions.question: Who will be using my data?
questions.answer: Your data will only be shared with researchers for research that has been approved by Children of the 90s. As with all research using your Children of the 90s data, linked data is processed using a unique ID number (like the barcode ID on your questionnaires). All your personal details (such as your name) will be removed, and researchers will not be able to link your data back to you.

questions.question: What if I change my mind about taking part in data linkage or any other aspect of Children of the 90s?
questions.answer: Taking part in the study is voluntary, you are free to do as much or as little as you like. If you change your mind about taking part in some or all of Children of the 90s then let us know via email to info@childrenofthe90s.ac.uk

questions.question: 1. Why doesn’t my card work?
questions.answer: If your card doesn’t permit you access to a building that; you either did have access to or; you thought you had access to please get in touch with your U Card administrator first.

questions.question: 2. What happens if my card is lost or stolen?
questions.answer: As soon as you think that you have lost your card or it has been stolen, please call Security Services on 0117 92 87848 (all calls to this number will be recorded for security purposes) 24-hours per day where we can deactivate all functions on your card immediately, this will prevent it being used in any U Card systems. If you subsequently find your card it can be re-activated without charge. Alternatively a replacement card can be obtained at Card Services at the Security Lodge in Royal Fort Gardens, Tyndall Avenue.  The old card will be permanently deactivated and there will be a charge for the new card.  See more information on lost cards .

questions.question: 3. I am a member of staff and I am also studying on a University programme. Do I need twoUCards?
questions.answer: No, you will only receive one staff U Card. Although you are enrolled on a programme, as a member of staff this takes precedence when library privileges, access rights, etc. are automatically assigned.

questions.question: 4. I am a student and a part-time member of staff. Do I need two UCards?
questions.answer: No, you will only receive one student U Card. If required, additional access rights can be assigned but this must be authorised by the appropriate faculty, department administration or building manager.

questions.question: 5. What do I do with my UCard when I leave the University?
questions.answer: Please ensure that your U Card is returned, with all University property, including keys, to your Head of Department on or before your last day of service or programme.

questions.question: 6. How do I use my new card with contact-less readers?
questions.answer: The U Card has a microchip embedded within it which stores your access code - instead of on a magnetic strip: this is the same technology as a bank card.  To use; simply touch the card to any reader where you see the U Card logo. Your U Card currently also has a magnetic strip which will allow you to use the existing readers, while they are replaced with smart card readers, without the need to do anything to your card.  Once the current readers have been replaced, future U Cards will not have a magnetic strip.

questions.question: 7. How can I have additional building access added to my card?
questions.answer: If you wish to have additional access added to your card, you must contact the appropriate U Card administrator .  Provided the change has been authorised by your head of department, the U Card Administrator is able to make any changes.

questions.question: 8. Why do I have to reactivate my card every 24 hours?
questions.answer: The new U Card system has been designed to work with both online (networked) and offline readers. In order to make sure offline reader information is as up-to-date as possible, and to prevent unreported lost or stolen cards being used by anyone, other than the card holder, your card needs to be regularly reactivated .  Reactivation is an automatic process which occurs every time you present your card to an online Salto reader (The type you see at main entrance(s)).  This needs to be done at least once every 24-hours otherwise your card will not be able to open any offline Salto door readers that you normally have access to.  All other functions remain unaffected.  Don’t worry if you are away or on leave for more than 24-hours, or out of the office for the weekend, you will just need to make sure that you reactivate your card at an online Salto reader on your return – your card will not lose any of its information.

questions.question: 9. If my card is lost or stolen, could someone just walk into a building?
questions.answer: We have built in a number of security features into the U Card system which will limit the time in which the card can be used, e.g. card reactivation for offline readers and biometric verification for high risk locations or buildings.  But you must still report your card as lost or stolen as soon as possible to Security Services on 0117 92 87848 (all calls to this number will be recorded for security purposes) 24-hours per day where we can deactivate all functions on your card immediately.  This will prevent it being used in any U Card systems.  If you subsequently find your card,  before a replacement is issued, it can be reactivated. If a replacement is needed straightaway, the process of printing a new card permanently deactivates your previous card.

questions.question: 10. Why do most doors now have a reader to exit instead of just a push button or handle?
questions.answer: Many walk-in thefts and burglaries that occur at the University are as a result of tailgating into a building, stealing something from a room or office and then finding the nearest external door to leave the building undetected.  Over the last few years, many fire doors have had a green emergency break-glass door release fitted to make the casual use of such doors less likely, and this has worked in reducing crime. However, many card access doors only had a reader on the outside with no need of a card to get out.  With the exception of a few areas, this arrangement has now changed so that a card is needed to open the door for exit.  You can still exit it in an emergency without a card by simply breaking the break-glass emergency door release.

questions.question: 11 How do I request more time for the door to remain open?
questions.answer: If a door on the access control system is held open for an extended period of time the door control will give an audible indication; short or long beeps; that it is being held open. Holding a door open will also cause a warning message to be displayed in the Security Services control room.

questions.question: 12. How do I get out in an emergency, has my safety been compromised?
questions.answer: No, your safety is of paramount importance to us.  In an emergency if the fire alarm is activated, doors in high-occupancy areas will automatically release.  If the fire alarm hasn’t operated or the door doesn’t open, simply break the green ‘break-glass’ button situated near them and the lock will release and you can then escape in the usual way.  However, where the ‘break-glass’ is broken this sounds an alarm nearby and it will notify the porters and the security control room that it has been activated.  A green emergency break glass is shown below:

questions.question: 13. Why is there no barcode on my card?
questions.answer: The library and sports centre systems now use the same microchip technology in their readers, so the barcode on your new card is no longer necessary.

questions.question: 14. Why do I not need a PIN anymore, has this made the card less secure?
questions.answer: In order to make it quick and easy for all of us to use the new card system, it was decided that a PIN was not necessary as many doors are currently open during the day and, even when they are not, tailgating occurs quite easily so you don’t even need a card. In other cases, PINs have been passed between users along with their card so negating the benefit of a secondary security measure in any case. Furthermore, the speed of using your card is increased by removing the need for a PIN: a PIN makes it less convenient and more likely a door will be propped open. In addition, those with manual dexterity problems or poor sight can struggle with using a keypad making them less user-friendly.

questions.question: 15. Why does my newUCard have less information on it?
questions.answer: The new U Card has been designed to make it clearer and easier to read.  We have removed job  titles as these soon become out of date.  We have also taken off the department names for staff for similar reasons.  However, students retain their faculty details to aid their academic support as well as an expiry date.  We have also placed as many non-essential details on the reverse of the card as possible.  This has allowed us to increase the size of the photograph and have room to designate different types of card holder, such as Library member, contractor, building visitor, etc to make it easy to quickly identify a person, particularly in the case of out-of-hours or restricted access areas.

questions.question: Is the course difficult?
questions.answer: Whether you are new to statistical modelling or an advanced user, we hope that you will find our materials useful. We recommend you test your current understanding of statistics by taking our prerequisites quiz .

questions.question: What statistical packages are used in the practicals?
questions.answer: MLwiN, R and Stata. As the MLwiN, R and Stata versions of each practical cover the same material, comparing across the practicals will help users to become familiar with the other package.

questions.question: What is the target audience for the materials? Do I need to have a strong background in statistics?
questions.answer: This set of modules is not aimed at the complete beginner in quantitative analysis. We rather expect most users will have some familiarity with many basic ideas and have some prior experience of traditional elementary statistical methods, perhaps up to two variable regression and correlation methods. They will usually also have had some exposure to introductory inference such as the ideas of confidence intervals and hypothesis testing.

questions.question: Are you an experienced quantitative researcher?
questions.answer: If you have a good understanding of multiple regressio - including the treatment of categorical explanatory variables and interaction effects - you may wish to skip to Module 4. If you do not feel fully confident in the application and interpretation of multiple regression, we recommend that you at least answer the quiz questions for Module 3 to test your understanding.

questions.question: I have attended one of the centre for multilevel modelling workshops. Do the online materials cover the same topics?
questions.answer: Module 4 and Module 5 cover the same material as the first part of our workshops, although in more detail and using different examples. We therefore strongly recommend working through these modules after attending the workshop to consolidate what you learnt before attempting to analyse your own data.

questions.question: I am planning to attend one of the centre for multilevel modelling workshops. Should I work through these materials first?
questions.answer: Our workshops assume an understanding and familiarity with the application of multiple regression. If you have not used multiple regression, or feel in need of a refresher, we strongly recommend that you work through Module 3 before the workshop. For those with less experience in statistical analysis, you may additionally find it helpful to study Module 1 and Module 2 .

questions.question: How can I test my understanding of the material?
questions.answer: You will find quiz questions interspersed throughout the modules to allow you to assess your understanding of the material.

questions.question: I do not have a copy of MLwiN. How can I do the practical exercises?
questions.answer: Download our LEMMA MLwiN training version (msi, 85.0 mb) for free. For other options such as using the full software where you can add your own data,: please see MLwiN downloads .

questions.question: I do not use MLwiN. Will I still find the materials useful?
questions.answer: Yes, much of the material can be used without software, or by users of software other than MLwiN.

questions.question: Do I have to pay to access the materials?
questions.answer: No. The materials can be accessed free-of-charge and downloaded by anyone. However, we do require users to register with us first.

questions.question: Why do I need to register?
questions.answer: We require you to register sothat we can collect data to help us to conduct and publish research into the learning of multilevel methodology and applications. We hope to study learning trajectories:

questions.question: Can I use the materials in my own teaching?
questions.answer: YES!

questions.question: How should I cite or reference the different LEMMA modules?
questions.answer: These learning materials were created as part of a research grant and we therefore ask that you cite them if you found them useful.

questions.question: Who designed the system?
questions.answer: The learning materials are kept in a course management system called Moodle . Moodle is an open source community project, and so has been designed by many people.

questions.question: Why can't we answer questions about the content of the materials?
questions.answer: The materials are very detailed and designed for self-learning. In particular, you can test your understanding of the materials by answering the quiz questions in each lesson of a module. You can retake the quiz as many times as you need to, to understand.

questions.question: How do I get to the course?
questions.answer: One easy way is to select this button

questions.question: When I double click on one of the worksheets for the LEMMA course, it opens with notepad not MLwiN
questions.answer: When I click on the icon for 5.1.wsz in Module 5.1 I seem to get a notepad file that has a lot of blank characters, not a data file.

questions.question: Can I make one extra copy of MLwiN for use at home ?
questions.answer: You can install more than one copy of MLwiN under a single user license, provided that you are the sole user.

questions.question: How much does MLwiN cost?
questions.answer: A list of prices is given on the order form .

questions.question: Am I entitled to academic discount?
questions.answer: Academic Discount is applicable if your purchase is for academic use in a university or school or if your organisation is a charity. It is not applicable to government organisations (including local authorities) or individual private purchases.

questions.question: Is there a special price for students?
questions.answer: Students are entitled to the standard academic discount of 40%.

questions.question: Can I purchase additional copies of MLwiN at a reduced price?
questions.answer: Once you have purchased MLwiN, you are entitled to purchase additional copies at a reduced price. Please see additional single user licence prices on our order form .

questions.question: What are the benefits of a site licence?
questions.answer: With a site licence you are licensed to make up to 50 copies of the software. The extension to the site licence allows you to make up to 250 copies within the site. If a person is employed at the site, they can take a copy home provided this is within the number of copies allocated to the site.

questions.question: I've already bought a single user license and need more copies for other staff - is it cheaper to buy additional copies or to buy a site licence?
questions.answer: The principal user of a single user license is entitled to purchase additional copies at a reduced price. If there are only a few other staff who need copies, it may be best to buy additional copies through the principal user.

questions.question: How do I upgrade my old version of MLwiN to the latest version?
questions.answer: You can upgrade your old version of MLwiN to the latest version for free by downloading the latest upgrade

questions.question: What are the conditions of purchase for MLwiN?
questions.answer: Please see our conditions of purchase

questions.question: I want to try out MLwiN before I buy it - is there an evaluation version?
questions.answer: You can download a training version of MLwiN for free. Note however that this is based on the older version 2.36.

questions.question: What are the system requirements for MLwiN?
questions.answer: Please see system requirements

questions.question: Who can I contact for technical advice before I buy MLwiN?
questions.answer: Please go to our technical support

questions.question: How do I order and pay for MLwiN?
questions.answer: Please see the MLwiN conditions of purchase .

questions.question: What are my payment options?
questions.answer: Please see the MLwiN conditions of purchase .

questions.question: Do I have to pay VAT on my MLwiN order?
questions.answer: VAT is payable if ordering from the UK.

questions.question: How long will it take for me to receive my copy of MLwiN?
questions.answer: Please allow 10 working days from receipt of order for delivery.

questions.question: I've lost my manual - can I get another one?
questions.answer: We no longer offer physical copies of manuals, however you can download the latest manuals for free.

questions.question: We are a software re-sale company and would like to purchase MLwiN for one of our customers - is this possible?
questions.answer: Sorry, we are unable to accept orders from re-sale companies. We do not deal with re-sale organisations under any circumstances. Customers must order directly from the MLwiN orders department. Please do not attempt to place an order through a re-sale company, as we will be unable to process the order.

questions.question: My question is not answered here - who should I contact?
questions.answer: Please email mlwin-order@bristol.ac.uk with sales enquiries

questions.question: What is a Visiting Fellow?
questions.answer: Visiting Fellows are scholars who visit for short periods of time or who are resident in the School of Education (SoE) for up to 12 months conducting their own research whilst benefiting from, and contributing to, the research culture of the SoE at Bristol.  For example, lecturers on sabbatical leave, overseas funded postdoctoral fellows or collaborators on projects.

questions.question: Is a Visiting Fellow the same as a Visiting Student?
questions.answer: No, Visiting Fellows are not students.  Visiting Fellows are affiliated to the Department for the purposes of conducting their own research.  They do not attend regular classes.  Visiting Fellows do not have structured supervision, but instead have multiple opportunities to engage with members of staff at the School of Education who have shared or related research interests.  If you are a student, please read our guidelines for Visiting Research Students .

questions.question: Is a Visiting Fellow the same as a Postdoctoral Fellow?
questions.answer: No.  Anyone interested in applying for funding to do a Postdoctoral Fellowship at SoE, Bristol, should visit our guidelines for Postdoctoral Fellows .

questions.question: What funding sources are there for Visiting Professors?
questions.answer: There are several sources, for example Leverhulme, British Academy and University of Bristol Benjamin Meaker schemes.  For more information do contact the Research & Enterprise Development (RED) team.

questions.question: Are there Immigration issues associated with Visiting Fellow applications?
questions.answer: Yes, but only for applicants who are citizens of countries outside of the European Economic Area (EEA) – please see the University's guidance for academic visitors .

questions.question: Does the School of Education offer funding for Visiting Fellows?
questions.answer: No.  Visiting Fellows must pay an affiliation/bench fee to the Department prior to their arrival in Bristol in order to receive Visiting Fellow status.  All travel and living expenses are the responsibility of the Visiting Fellow, not the Department.

questions.question: How can I pay the affiliation/bench fee?
questions.answer: Arrangements for paying the affiliation/bench fee should be made with Shirley Stobart .

questions.question: How do I arrange accommodation for my visit to Bristol?
questions.answer: Visiting Fellows must make their own accommodation arrangements however you can check the University's information for staff seeking accommodation .

questions.question: I want to improve my English whilst acting as a Visiting Fellow at Bristol.  Is this possible?
questions.answer: We ask that applicants have a level of English that is of a standard that is suitable for academic work.  If you would like to take English classes, they are available from the University’s Language Centre.  You would need to pay the tuition fee yourself.  For further details, please visit the Language Centre website .

questions.question: What happens after I apply?
questions.answer: We will send you an acknowledgement of your application form within 21 days of receiving it. If you do not receive an acknowledgement, then please contact us as this may mean it has not arrived. All application forms will be passed to the Course Director, Tom Sperlinger. Interviews for this course will be held in July 2014. If you are likely to be away during that month, you are encouraged to apply early so that we can arrange an alternative interview date.

questions.question: What will I be asked at interview?
questions.answer: One aim of the interview will be to give you a detailed picture of the course. So, the interview is partly an opportunity for you to ask questions. We will ask you about: your reasons for wanting to study on the degree, what you enjoy reading, how the course would fit in with your other commitments, and your aims and ambitions after you finish the degree.

questions.question: I don’t have A-Levels (or) I don’t have GCSE English (or) I didn’t do well at school… can I apply?
questions.answer: Yes! You do not need to have previous qualifications to apply for the course, if you can demonstrate that you are motivated and enthusiastic, that you have read a range of literature, and that you are committed to the idea of studying at a higher level. If you do apply without prior qualifications, we may ask you to complete a short piece of written work as part of the application process. You will receive advice on this before you are asked to do it.

questions.question: How do you decide who gets a place on the course?
questions.answer: As well as looking at prior qualifications or at evidence of your interest in the subject, we will be looking for students who are motivated, enthusiastic and committed; who have strong reasons for wanting to study on this particular degree in a part-time mode; and who can demonstrate that they will be able to manage the demands of study at this level.

questions.question: How can I fit my studies around work and/or family?
questions.answer: The English Literature and Community Engagement (ELCE) course is part of Bristol’s commitment to offering more flexible learning opportunities – it is designed for people who have to balance studying with work, family, or other parts of their life. The course is taught on approximately thirty evenings per year. By concentrating the contact hours within one night per week, we hope to make the degree accessible to those with other commitments. On top of this, you would normally be expected to complete approximately 10-12 hours of work in your own time each week.

questions.question: How does this degree relate to the BA English that runs during the day?
questions.answer: The BA ELCE is designed to draw on the strengths of the BA English at Bristol, which runs during the day, particular through a commitment to studying a wide variety of literature in English across many different periods. It aims to offer a similar programme within more flexible hours and in combination with a unique community engagement element. Both BAs in English are taught by the same staff and validated by the same exam board – that is, overseen by the same examiners at Bristol and externals from other universities – so the same academic standards are applied on both programmes.

questions.question: Is there an option to switch to full-time study?
questions.answer: Students may request to switch to full-time study after completing the Certificate (at the end of year two) or Diploma (at the end of year four). This will, however, depend on circumstances and student numbers in any given year and it cannot be offered as a guaranteed option.

questions.question: Six years is a long time! What happens if I do not complete the degree?
questions.answer: Students who for any reason are unable to complete all six years can still complete one of two awards: a Certificate (after two years) or Diploma (after four) in English Literature and Community Engagement. It may also be possible to transfer credits accumulated on this course to another institution.

questions.question: Does a university like Bristol really want to take mature students like me?
questions.answer: Yes! The University has a proud tradition of involvement in adult education and community engagement and we welcome the different perspective and knowledge mature students bring to their studies. In the English Department in 2011-12, over 250 people have studied on short and longer part-time courses. Statistical information gathered from these courses shows that we recruit students crossing all barriers of age, gender, ethnicity, disability, social class, and prior educational achievement.

questions.question: Isn’t it very expensive to go to university?
questions.answer: We realise that financing a degree, or any long-term programme of study, can seem daunting, particularly if you have other responsibilities. But there is help available, both from the Government and from the University (see the information on Fees and Funding above). The new systems of loans being introduced for part-time students in 2012-13 means that any student starting an undergraduate degree for the first time will not have to pay any of their fees up front.

questions.question: Are the community engagement units compulsory?
questions.answer: The community engagement units are a compulsory part of the course. However, they are also an especially flexible element of it, designed to fit with each student’s interests and other commitments. Some of our students undertake a project at work, for example, or at a community setting with which they already have some involvement. Some of our students feel nervous about undertaking this element of the course before it begins, but each student is able to develop a project that is appropriate for them.

questions.question: How will the community engagement work be organised?
questions.answer: The first year of study will offer some background information and training to prepare each student for the community engagement work. During the second year, we will help you to find a suitable project in the community. You may, for example, wish to run a reading group at work or in a community setting with which you are familiar (where agreement is reached with the employer or other relevant persons); or we will be offering a range of projects organized with Bristol Libraries and a number of community groups; or you may wish to use what you are learning in other ways.

questions.question: What's it like being a mature student?
questions.answer: You can see some more, general information on being a mature student at Bristol here .

questions.question: 1. How do I get a University login and access to e-mail and other IT systems?
questions.answer: All new staff and students are automatically registered for a University login and Microsoft Outlook account (for email and on-line calendar) when they join the University. To obtain details of passwords, email addresses, etc., users should either contact the IT Service Desk or use the self service web page to set their own passwords.

questions.question: 2. How do I get security access to my workplace?
questions.answer: The University uses a personal smart card for building access access control. Please see the relevant web pages on the Security Services web site and on the Card Services site to obtain or replace a card.

questions.question: 3. My information is wrong on the Contact Directory. How do I change it?
questions.answer: Contact Directory information is derived from personal and employment data in MyERP. For further details on how to make and request changes to MyERP, see the guide to updating your details in MyERP .

questions.question: 4. When is pay day?
questions.answer: Salary is paid monthly by credit transfer into your nominated bank/building society account. This is normally on the 26th day of the month (or the last working day beforehand if 26th falls on a weekend or bank holiday). Pay day is usually earlier in December.

questions.question: 5. What should I do if I have questions about my payslip, pension or tax and national insurance contributions?
questions.answer: Questions about your salary, national insurance or income tax should be directed to the Payroll Office. Questions about pension contributions, schemes and entitlement should be directed to the Pensions Office.

questions.question: 6. What should I do if I’m unwell and can’t come in to work?
questions.answer: You or someone acting on your behalf must notify the relevant person in your department by telephone as soon as possible (normally by 10:00am) on your first day of absence. You will need to give the reason for your absence and the date you expect to return to work and/or agree when you will next be in contact with your department with further information. When you return to work, you will need to complete a self-certification form in MyERP . If your absence lasts for eight consecutive days or more (including weekends), however, you will need to submit a doctor’s certificate covering the total period of your absence. Throughout your absence, you must keep your manager informed about your progress and your likely date of return. For full details, please see section 7 of the University Terms and Conditions of Employment and Section A (Sickness Reporting Procedure) of the Health and Absence Policy .

questions.question: 7. What sick pay am I entitled to?
questions.answer: Entitlement to sick pay depends on length of service with the University. For full details, please see section 7 of the University Terms and Conditions of Employment .

questions.question: 8. What holiday am I entitled to?
questions.answer: For full details of holiday entitlement, please refer to Section 4 of the particular terms and conditions of employment for Staff on Grades A to I and/or to Section 3 for Staff on Grades J and Above . Further information can also be found within the University's Annual leave guidance .

questions.question: 9. I am part time staff. How do I find out my pro rata holiday entitlement?
questions.answer: Full details of how the pro rata holiday entitlement for part time staff is calculated are given in section 4.4 of the particular terms and conditions of employment for Staff on Grades A to I and to section 3.4 for Staff on Grades J and Above .

questions.question: 10. How do I change my name/title?
questions.answer: You will need to bring any relevant documentation to your HR Faculty Team , where a copy will be taken as evidence of the change. The copy will be kept on your file and the original will be returned to you. Your electronic records will then be updated.

questions.question: 11. I am expecting/adopting a child. Where can I find out about maternity/paternity leave?
questions.answer: There is a range of information available for new and expectant parents on the University's parents and carers webpages . Staff can find all of our home and family policies and guidance on the Staff and PGR Intranet including maternity leave, paternity and partner leave, adoption leave, shared parental leave. For prospective staff, summaries of the University's work-life balance policies , including our home and family policies can be found on our Working at Bristol pages.

questions.question: 12. Does the University offer childcare?
questions.answer: The University Day Nursery is a not-for-profit workplace nursery overseen by a trustee group of parent staff and students. It gives priority to student parents but also offers places to staff where available. Woodland House Nursery is a private nursery affiliated to the University and giving priority to University staff.

questions.question: 13. Are there health/sports facilities for staff?
questions.answer: Sports, Exercise and Health offer a wide range of facilities and activities available to staff, students and the community.

questions.question: 14. Are there parking facilities at the University?
questions.answer: Demand for car parking at the University is high and parking spaces are limited. If you are able to, please consider travelling by alternative means of transport . Parking permits are allocated based on strict eligibility criteria so please check to see whether you are eligible to apply.

questions.question: How does the job evaluation system and grade structure affect the recruitment process?
questions.answer: The answers to some key questions on job evaluation and the new grade structure are outlined below.

questions.question: If I am recruiting to a newly created job, how do I get this evaluated?
questions.answer: It is important to ensure that new job roles are evaluated at the outset, prior to the vacancy details being submitted through the eRecruit system for advertising. The exception to this are jobs in the Research and Teaching job family, for which the recruiting manager needs to select the appropriate academic career pathway and role profile .

questions.question: If I am recruiting to an existing job but wish to make changes to the job description, what is the position with getting it evaluated?
questions.answer: It is important to ensure that existing jobs that have substantially changed are evaluated at the outset, prior to the vacancy details being submitted through the eRecruit system for advertising.

questions.question: How does the recruitment and selection process for academic roles differ from other vacancies?
questions.answer: The principles and procedures outlined in the guidance on recruitment and selection apply to all University of Bristol vacancies. However, Chair appointments , academic and senior administrative roles and clinical academic roles are also subject to some specific requirements. Human Resources will work closely with you on co-ordinating the recruitment and selection process for these vacancies.

questions.question: Under what circumstances am I able to recruit on a fixed term or other short term contract?
questions.answer: Legislation exists to limit the use of successive fixed term contracts and prevent fixed term employees being treated less favourably than similar permanent employees. We believe this provides:

questions.question: What responsibilities are there to consider people who need to be redeployed because they are coming to the end of a fixed term contract or otherwise at risk of redundancy?
questions.answer: The University has a legal and moral obligation to give every opportunity for individuals who are at risk of redundancy to obtain suitable alternative employment with the University. Effective redeployment also retains valuable skills and knowledge within the University. The University's Redeployment of Staff policy outlines the procedures that have been put in place to enable this. Your Faculty/Divisional Human Resources Manager can also provide advice on this process.

questions.question: When can a vacancy be restricted to internal candidates only?
questions.answer: Professional and Administrative Grades G-J are subject to internal advertising in line with the existing Trade Union agreements. An internal candidate is defined as a member of University staff or worker who has employment with the University as an open-ended , fixed-term or Teaching Support staff member, via an Internship or Apprenticeship, as an agency staff worker who has been working for more than 12 weeks at the University,​ or as TSS Admin/Clerical worker. PGR students can also access internal vacancies.

questions.question: What is the position with temps applying for jobs?
questions.answer: Full guidance on references can be found at: http://www.bristol.ac.uk/hr/resourcing/resourcing-guidance-and-process/selection/references.html

questions.question: What part should references play in the selection process?
questions.answer: Full guidance on references can be found at: http://www.bristol.ac.uk/hr/resourcing/resourcing-guidance-and-process/selection/references.html

questions.question: How many hours a week are students allowed to work?
questions.answer: The University's advice to all its students is not to work more than 15 hours a week while studying full time. International students on a Student visa (formerly known as Tier 4) are furthermore subject to legal restrictions on working hours as part of the conditions of their visa. To learn more about how many hours a week you can work, please check on the Student Visa Webpages

questions.question: What makes this department at the University of Bristol unique?
questions.answer: Our courses are designed to provide a solid foundation in the basics of mathematics. They progress to include advanced study of specialist subjects at the cutting edge of research, as well as options that are more vocationally focused.

questions.question: How does the research at the school benefit the experience of the students at the school? Can you give any examples of this?
questions.answer: The reputation of Mathematics at Bristol attracts the very best lecturers, who want to be part of our flourishing research environment. This means that our teaching is informed by cutting-edge research across a wide range of exciting topics; as you advance, you’ll have the chance to choose higher-level mathematics units, such as topics like quantum mechanics or mathematical biology.

questions.question: What does the school do to welcome students when they first start at Bristol? Are there any student-led societies linked to the department?
questions.answer: Our student society Matrix provides several opportunities to make friends on your course; they run social events, guest lectures and a ‘Family’ support system where students in advanced years mentor first years. Matrix also manages a series of networks for female and non-binary, LGBT, and BAME students that you can join.

questions.question: What is the first year timetable like for those studying this course?
questions.answer: Our first year provides students with a robust foundation in mathematics. You will study core units in Analysis and Linear Algebra, as well as units in Applied Mathematics, Pure Mathematics and Probability and Statistics.

questions.question: What support does the school offer to new students?
questions.answer: Our teaching is designed to help you make the transition to university-level study. Small-group tutorials and group project work allows you to collaborate with other students and make friends. You will also work closely with your personal tutor during your first year, establishing a relationship that will guide you throughout your degree. In the first year, students have regular tutorials, problems classes and workshops.

questions.question: How will the course set students up for their future careers?
questions.answer: Our graduates are highly sought-after by employers for their strong analytical, communication and organisational skills and a number of our courses qualify for accreditation by professional bodies .

questions.question: Are there any employers or other initiatives that the school works with for industry placements?
questions.answer: We run a facilitated placement scheme for students involving a large spread of organisations from small start-ups to financial companies and large manufacturers and utilities that the School has existing research links with, or who are key recruiters of mathematics graduates.

questions.question: What do graduates go on to do after studying this course at Bristol?
questions.answer: A significant number continue with postgraduate study, while many graduates find employment in accountancy, finance, management, teaching and a wide variety of other sectors. Examples of organisations our graduates work for include the Civil Service, TeachFirst, HBSC, KPMG, Sky, Deloitte and Cambridge Brain Sciences, as well as a range of smaller start-ups.

questions.question: What opportunities are there to study abroad as part of this course?
questions.answer: We offer two programmes with study abroad; Mathematics with Study in Continental Europe, and Mathematics with Study Abroad.

questions.question: What are the facilities like on campus that students will use to study this course?
questions.answer: At Bristol you will study in a fully refurbished Grade II-listed building at the heart of campus. From quiet study areas to new collaboration spaces and even boards in the courtyard garden, the whole building is designed to support creative mathematics, wherever that light-bulb moment strikes.

questions.question: How many hours (on average) are required outside of lectures for additional work and study?
questions.answer: This may vary from week to week. We design our courses aiming for students to be able to complete both scheduled classes and additional study within a normal working week through the term and exam periods. As a ballpark figure, we recommend an average of three hours per unit of additional study in your first year, or 18 hours per week.

questions.question: How do assessments work for the department?
questions.answer: Most units are assessed mainly by exam and we run two exam periods: in January and in May/June.

questions.question: What would you say are the main differences between studying at school and study at university?
questions.answer: Studying Mathematics at university is more challenging, and more interesting than at school or college; our students enjoy the satisfaction of sticking with a difficult problem to find the answer. At university, there’s a far wider range of topics to choose from. This means you can try lots of different types of mathematics to see what you enjoy - which might be different from what you preferred at school. This flexibility allows students to choose to specialise based on their interests.

questions.question: What examples are there of final year projects or dissertations that students have worked on when they study this course?
questions.answer: Due to our broad research base, you can pick from a wide range of topics. Examples of recent final year projects our students have worked on include:

questions.question: What could I do over the summer to prepare for starting this course?
questions.answer: The units you will take in your first year will build on what you learned in A-levels, but will soon go significantly beyond that, both in content and in the style of mathematics. The following books are good references to help you prepare for this transition and are a useful study companion for the first year. Once you have registered they will both be available online free of charge via the University Library

questions.question: Questions?
questions.answer: Explore our comprehensive FAQ pages or contact us for help and support.

questions.question: 1. How do I apply for a place?
questions.answer: Check the nursery admissions policy . Fill in the Application Form 2024 (Office document, 50kB) and return it to the Nursery Manager .

questions.question: 2. How long is the waiting list?
questions.answer: Long! For up to date information contact the nursery manager. Apply as early as you can. If your child has yet to be born write 'unknown' for child's forename on the application form.

questions.question: 3. Can I get day care for my child at short notice?
questions.answer: Generally the University Day Nursery can not provide care for non-registered children at short notice. However we can sometimes accomodate children of visiting academics or short-term students if we have availabilty at the time.

questions.question: 5. What is the minimum number of sessions that I can apply for?
questions.answer: 2 full days or four sessions, morning and/or afternoon, with or without lunch.

questions.question: 6. When can my child return to the nursery after illness?
questions.answer: Children must be well enough to attend a full nursery day. They cannot return to nursery unless they are clear of a temperature for 24 hours.

questions.question: 7. Can the nursery staff administer medication?
questions.answer: We believe that children with long - term medical needs have the same rights of admission to the setting as other children. We will work with staff, parents, children and relevant healthcare professionals to enable this to happen whilst ensuring the safety of staff and children and recognising that there maybe circumstances in which this is unable to occur e.g. with complex medical procedures.

questions.question: 8. What happens when my child leaves the nursery?
questions.answer: If you need to remove your child from the nursery please give at least 8 weeks notice. Failure to provide this could result in loss of your deposit.

questions.question: 9. Can I reduce my child's sessions at nursery for a limited period of time (for example, whilst I'm on maternity leave)?
questions.answer: You can reduce your child's attendance at the nursery at any time using the and giving 8 weeks notice. However, we cannot guarantee that those sessions will still be available when you wish to increase your child's attendance again. It is important to maintain maximum occupancy to keep fees as low as possible.

questions.question: What is Germ Defence and who made it?
questions.answer: Germ Defence is a website that gives simple advice to reduce the spread of COVID-19 in the home. It was designed by doctors, scientists and psychologists and was tested with 20,000 people during the swine ‘flu pandemic in 2009. It has recently been updated for COVID-19.

questions.question: How will using Germ Defence help me?
questions.answer: During the swine ‘flu pandemic, people who used Germ Defence had fewer cold/’flu infections and they were less severe. People also saw their doctor less often. We have updated Germ Defence for COVID-19 - which is caught in the same way as other viruses - and we now want to find out how effective Germ Defence is during this pandemic.

questions.question: Why did my practice contact me?
questions.answer: To find out how well Germ Defence works against COVID-19, we have asked half the GP practices in England to send a weblink to the Germ Defence website to all their patients aged 16 and over. Afterwards, we will look at national NHS data to see if patients from the practices who sent out the weblink have less COVID-19 (and other cold/’flu viruses) than patients from the practices who didn’t.

questions.question: Will you be using my data?
questions.answer: No, we won’t be collecting any personal data about anyone.

questions.question: What if I don’t speak or read English well?
questions.answer: Germ Defence is available in more than 20 languages, and these translations can be accessed from the main page on the Germ Defence website.

questions.question: Do I need to sign up to take part?
questions.answer: No, you don’t need to sign up - just follow the weblink that your GP practice gave you to the Germ Defence website.

questions.question: Should I send this link on to my friends and family?
questions.answer: Please don’t pass on the individual weblink you received from your GP practice to anyone else. You can send details about the Germ Defence website to others using the ‘share’ button at the end of the Germ Defence website or you can print out our infographic and give it to people who don’t use the internet. Just visit the Germ Defence website to find out how to do this.

questions.question: What if I can’t use the internet?
questions.answer: If you are not able to access a computer or smart phone to read about Germ Defence, we hope you can ask someone else to visit the website for you and print off the infographic provided.

questions.question: Who has approved the study?
questions.answer: The study has been approved by Yorkshire & The Humber (Leeds West) Research Ethics Committee on behalf of the Health Research Authority (reference 20/YH/0261). Chris Whitty, the Chief Medical Officer (CMO) for England, has made this a national priority project and it also has the support of the Royal College of General Practitioners.

questions.question: Further questions or concerns about Germ Defence?
questions.answer: Please contact the Germ Defence team by e-mailing germdefence-study@bristol.ac.uk .

questions.question: How to use the print submission system
questions.answer: Yes. Upload the files you want to merge. Choose the library tab; select the appropriate files; and press the merge icon. You can also add blank pages and/or change the order of the files.

questions.question: My job has more than one file. Can I merge them before I send them?
questions.answer: Yes. Upload the files you want to merge. Choose the library tab; select the appropriate files; and press the merge icon. You can also add blank pages and/or change the order of the files.

questions.question: Can I submit more than one file per request?
questions.answer: Please ensure that you only place one print order per job request.  If you have the duplicate  print instructions for each job i.e. A1 matt poster for a student hand in, you can send a zipped file through the Print Submission system.  The system will not be able to provide a quote at this stage.

questions.question: How do I track a job?
questions.answer: To track the order, select the 'Orders' option in the print submission system.

questions.question: How should I supply files?
questions.answer: Please supply a PDF file (at least 300 dpi, or dots per inch) for printing.

questions.question: Which students need to submit outcomes?
questions.answer: UKRI will only be asking for students who are in the third or later year of their studies to submit their outcomes, i.e. students whose awards started on or before February 2020 .

questions.question: Is it mandatory?
questions.answer: It varies by funder. For the 2023 submission period (6 February - 4pm 16 March 2023), Researchfish submission is optional for all UKRI Research Council student awards, unless advised otherwise. Other funders such as the NIHR do require submission as a condition of grant.

questions.question: What do I need to do?
questions.answer: - Register your details using the login details provided by Researchfish

questions.question: How do I login to Researchfish?
questions.answer: Log in to Researchfish at: https://app.researchfish.com/researcher_home

questions.question: What do I need to report and how do I do it?
questions.answer: When you log on to Researchfish you can click the “My Awards” button on the left-hand menu. Click an award then you can enter details of outcomes by clicking sections on the left of the page (publications, collaborations, etc.), and following the instructions. It is important that you then associate each outcome with the relevant award(s) as shown in https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=L-RG1H4zfGo&list=PLdHIODRLeCdPMl5J7YKBtAd6RzFNC9sEY&index=1&t=19s In this section your studentship will be listed on the right of the screen.

questions.question: What happens if I don’t have any outcomes to report?
questions.answer: It is very common for most impacts to occur towards the end of a project or after it has finished. Do not worry if you have nothing to report until towards the end of your PhD, just submit a blank response. You are still expected to complete the submission process, however, even if there are no outcomes to report.

questions.question: What do I do and what does my supervisor do?
questions.answer: UKRI has had supervisors added to studentships as Team Members so they have the ability to help you add attributions if they so wish. Please note that the supervisors will not be able to submit the return , this is the responsibility of the student. Additional supervisors can be added to your studentship details as ‘team members’.

questions.question: Can I use the publications I have added to Pure?
questions.answer: If you have publications already listed in Pure, you can copy them directly into Researchfish using the publication ID, e.g. DOI, PubMed ID or Scopus ID.

questions.question: When do I have to finish entering data?
questions.answer: You can enter data at any time but you will need to confirm that all of your information is accurate and complete during the annual submission period. The next submission period is 6 February 2023 to 4pm 16 March 2023 . You will receive a reminder email to finish entering and submit your data. Successful submissions will be confirmed by the system via email.

questions.question: Where can I find further information?
questions.answer: For general guidance and support please contact your supervisor.

questions.question: How to get a referral
questions.answer: Speak to your manager or HR contact to request a referral to the Occupational Health Service if you feel this would assist you in managing your health at work.

questions.question: What is an activity monitor?
questions.answer: If you are taking part in the study you will be asked to wear an activity monitor (also called an accelerometer) for seven days in a row. The monitors are small devices worn on a belt around the waist. They tell us how active you are – but not where you are or what you are doing. The monitor works by measuring how much you move throughout the day.

questions.question: When should I wear the activity monitor?
questions.answer: You should wear the activity monitor at all times – at home, whilst at school, and over the weekend. We ask you to put the belt on as soon as you wake up in the morning and to wear it as much possible until you go to bed at night. If you go to any clubs, such as brownies / cubs or sports clubs, you should still keep it on. The more you wear it, the better the information that you give us.

questions.question: When should I not wear the activity monitor?
questions.answer: There are only three occasions when you should take off the activity monitor:

questions.question: How should I wear the activity monitor?
questions.answer: You should wear the belt below your waist, so that the red box sits on your right hip. There is a small black bump (that looks like a button) on one side of the box, this black bump should always be facing upwards when the belt is in being worn.

questions.question: What happens if I forget to bring back my activity monitor?
questions.answer: If you forget to bring your belt back on the collection day, please bring it in on the next school day. It still holds valuable data, so we really need to collect it back in as soon as possible.

questions.question: What happens if I lose my activity monitor?
questions.answer: Hopefully this will not happen as you will be wearing it most of the time. However, if you think you may have lost it, please try as hard as you can to find it again and to return it to us, even if it is late. Please let us know as soon as possible if you think you may have lost your monitor as we work very hard to try and get them all back quickly.

questions.question: Why don’t all the schools get the Action 3:30 clubs?
questions.answer: The division into ‘intervention’ and ‘comparison’ schools means that half the schools will receive the clubs and half will not. This is because we need to test how physically active the children in the intervention schools are compared with children who do not receive the clubs. The children in the comparison schools are just as important to our research as the children in who receive the clubs.

questions.question: What happens to the data collected? Is it safe?
questions.answer: We take data protection very seriously. The information we collect on all the children is stored securely. All questionnaires and computerised data are stored against an ID and not against the children’s’ names. This means that when the data is analysed it is anonymous, so the researchers will not know which child the information belongs to.

questions.question: Can I apply direct to the University of Bristol for a funded place?
questions.answer: No, it is not possible to apply direct. All applicants must apply through the Association of Educational Psychologists .

questions.question: What are the entry requirements?
questions.answer: An upper second-class honours degree in psychology (or equivalent qualification) that confers Graduate Basis for Chartered Membership (GBC) with the British Psychological Society . Applications with a 2:2 and relevant experience may be considered.

questions.question: When is the closing date for applications?
questions.answer: Please refer to the Association of Educational Psychologist's online application website for full details.

questions.question: Will I be called to interview?
questions.answer: Only shortlisted applicants will be invited to attend an interview. Interviews are usually held in February each year, prior to the September intake.

questions.question: How many funded places are available each year?
questions.answer: The University of Bristol welcomes ten funded students in September/October each year. It is not possible to apply on a self-funded basis and/or direct to the University of Bristol for this progamme.

questions.question: How competitive is the programme?
questions.answer: The University of Bristol usually receives between 150 - 200 applications for ten funded places. We usually interview between 35 - 45 candidates.

questions.question: My application was not successful last year. Can I reapply this year?
questions.answer: Yes. The course is extremely competitive and the standard of applicants is very high. It is quite usual for applicants to apply in successive years.

questions.question: I am applying as a mature student. Will I be disadvantaged in anyway?
questions.answer: We are looking for the best candidates in terms of skills, experience and knowledge. Age is irrelevant.

questions.question: Can I study part-time or via distance learning?
questions.answer: No. The course is run on a full time basis only. The course is extremely demanding. We would strongly advise students not to work (even part-time) to assist with funding.

questions.question: I'm in my final year of a psychology degree. Can I apply now?
questions.answer: No. Only graduates can apply – with a degree recognised by the BPS (Graduate Basis for Chartered Membership (GBC)).

questions.question: How much work experience with children is required?
questions.answer: Successful applicants will be expected to have at least two years full time experience (or the equivalent) before the start of the course. Experience should be working with children in an educational, child care or community setting. Sustained voluntary experience over a period of time is relevant. Applicants are referred to the AEP website on this topic.

questions.question: Does my undergraduate degree have sufficient psychology modules for recognition by the British Psychological Society for Graduate Basis for Chartered Membership?
questions.answer: You should contact the British Psychological Society to confirm whether your degree has sufficient psychology modules. The BPS can also provide details of approved conversion courses available to you.

questions.question: Will a teaching qualification (PGCE) strengthen my application?
questions.answer: No. The PGCE programme is only relevant for those with a desire to teach.

questions.question: Can I use credits from qualifications obtained for the Doctor for Educational Psychology programme?
questions.answer: No.

questions.question: What funding is available?
questions.answer: Successful applicants for a funded place will have the tuition fees for all 3 years paid in addition to the bursary of £15,950 in year one. For years two and three, students obtain a placement bursary as a trainee educational psychologist with an Educational Psychology Service.

questions.question: If I get a place on the course, will I need to organise my own placements in years one to three?
questions.answer: Year one placements are organised in Bristol schools and in a South West Psychology Service, or one near your home address, if possible. In years two and three, trainees’ placement bursaries are allocated to services taking account of your address and other additional factors.

questions.question: Will I have to relocate to Bristol either in year one or years two and three?
questions.answer: In year one, the programme is strongly Bristol-based. As it promotes a collaborative model, reasonable access to colleagues and tutors is important during this year. Attendance at the University in years two and three is reduced. As previously mentioned, in years two and three, trainees’ placement bursaries are allocated to services taking account of your address and other additional factors. This may well result in re-location depending on where bursaries are offered.

questions.question: When can I apply for entry?
questions.answer: The deadline for overseas applications is 20 June 2025 and the deadline for home applications is 4 July 2025 .

questions.question: How do I apply?
questions.answer: Applications are made via the online application system .

questions.question: Is there an application fee?
questions.answer: No.

questions.question: I have applied before - do I need to re-apply?
questions.answer: Yes, via the online application system .

questions.question: Are my undergraduate qualifications appropriate?
questions.answer: We require a 2:1 in any academic discipline. Lesser degrees will be considered if there is evidence of substantial relevant work experience.

questions.question: What are the English Language requirements for the course?
questions.answer: An English Language test will be required. Please refer to the programme prospectus page for information.

questions.question: What accommodation is on offer?
questions.answer: Please refer to the University’s main accommodation webpage .

questions.question: How is the University of Bristol programme run?
questions.answer: The MSc programme is planned and managed by University of Bristol. This is a two year master's programme designed to comply with University requirements, QAA guidelines at master's level and with the requirements of Social Work England and Department of Health. In addition, all students are expected to meet professional requirements in accordance with the Professional Capabilities Framework (PCF) .

questions.question: Is the programme an approved professional social work course?
questions.answer: The MSc Social Work has the status of an ‘approved programme’ with Social Work England . This two-year programme is provided under the new framework for Social Work qualifications. It is a joint professional practice and academic award. On successful completion of the programme you will be eligible to apply for registration with Social Work England .

questions.question: What are the Bristol University fees?
questions.answer: Please refer to the University's fees and funding pages.

questions.question: What is the news about bursary support for MSc students?
questions.answer: Each year, the NHS allocates a certain number of bursaries to students on our MSc in Social Work. Following interview, the University notifies successful students if they are being recommended for an NHS bursary. Our bursaries are restricted to students ordinarily resident in England. If you are interested in being nominated for a bursary, early application to our programme is advised. For full details of eligibility criteria, students should contact the NHS Business Services Authority https://www.nhsbsa.nhs.uk/social-work-students .

questions.question: What financial help is available from the University?
questions.answer: Please refer to the Social Work fees and funding page.

questions.question: What is the selection procedure?
questions.answer: The following criteria are used when considering applications:

questions.question: How is the programme structured?
questions.answer: The organisation of teaching and learning on this course is modular. Assessment is based on written work, direct assessment of practice, various forms of continuous assessment, and participation in classes and workshops.

questions.question: Can the programme be undertaken part-time?
questions.answer: No. The MSc Social Work is a full-time programme; it starts in mid September in year one and runs for two years.

questions.question: What social work research is happening in the University?
questions.answer: The School for Policy Studies has an outstanding national and international reputation for the quality and quantity of research in social work as well as in social policy . The social work team is actively involved in many research studies.

questions.question: Do many mature students undertake the course?
questions.answer: Social work is an exciting career for a wide range of people of all ages, and this is reflected in the breadth of backgrounds of our social work students. The broad age-range represented by our student cohorts is a very positive aspect of our programme as it allows for collaborative exchange of ideas and peer learning.

questions.question: How much previous experience do I need and in what fields of work?
questions.answer: Ideally, six months experience is the minimum requirement ; this can be from a mixture of full or part time and can be paid or voluntary. See our relevant experience (Office document, 36kB) document for more information.

questions.question: How will my work be assessed?
questions.answer: Most of the units are assessed by extended essays, case studies and / or presentations which are designed to apply theory and research to practice and policy. There are two examinations; a Law exam and Human Development exam. Practice placements are assessed jointly by skilled and experienced practice educators, practice supervisors and a member of the university staff. You will be required to compile a portfolio of work based on your practice with service users and carers, including critical reflections and structured observations of your work. These portfolios are reviewed by a Practice Assessment Panel (PAP), a team of people who represent partner agencies, the Forum, and the University. The programme concludes with a research-based dissertation project.

questions.question: How is the practice placement organised?
questions.answer: There are two placements, the first is 70 days and second is 100 days. Practice placements are arranged by the practice learning co-ordinator in partnership with social work and social care agencies.

questions.question: Where will the practice placement take place?
questions.answer: The placement co-ordinators negotiate placements for students in partnership with local authority, voluntary and independent sector providers. At least one of your placements will be in a practice setting where you will be able to learn about statutory social work tasks and skills and subsequently to demonstrate your capability in these respects. The university’s partner agencies include Bristol City Council, North Somerset Council, Somerset County Council and South Gloucestershire Council. We also collaborate with other neighbouring authorities in the South West and have a number of established links with Voluntary and Independent Sector agencies across the region.

questions.question: Can I do a placement overseas?
questions.answer: Opportunities for overseas placements are not normally part of the University of Bristol social work programme.

questions.question: How much academic and/or personal support can I expect from both the University and the course staff?
questions.answer: All students are allocated a personal tutor for the duration of the programme. For each practice placement, students have a qualified practice educator , and in some circumstances , a practice supervisor who , together with the student and personal tutor make up the student’s Practice Learning Team.

questions.question: I am an international student, can I apply?
questions.answer: As an international student, you are welcome to apply. It is important for you to note that:

questions.question: What support is available for students with young children or other caring responsibilities?
questions.answer: The MSc Social Work is a full-time, intensive and demanding programme. It has been designed, as far as possible, to allow for students to study whilst still meeting family commitments. However, we encourage prospective students to discuss the requirements they may have, together with associated practicalities, particularly in view of placement allocation. Please note that quality placements are at a premium and that it is important to be flexible.

questions.question: Will I get any credits for previous academic experience?
questions.answer: If you have successfully completed postgraduate level modules on another social work education programme, you should discuss your situation with the admissions tutor, who may be contacted via sps-pgadmissions@bristol.ac.uk . Please note that you cannot count academic credits gained on a programme for which you have already been awarded a degree.

questions.question: Can you recommend any pre application reading?
questions.answer: There are quite a few books about social work on the market, and many interesting articles and papers you can access on the internet, such as:

questions.question: How to apply
questions.answer: To apply for one of our University-managed staff properties, please complete our long-stay or short-stay online application form.

questions.question: How to apply
questions.answer: You don't need to apply for this discount. If you are eligible, the discount will be applied automatically to your fees invoice.

questions.question: Am I able to have confirmation that I’m eligible for the discount before I register at the university?
questions.answer: Currently, we cannot advise students on eligibility before their registration at the University. This page provides detailed guidance to assist you with your planning.

questions.question: Is my intended or alumni course eligible?
questions.answer: Here is a list of programmes that are not eligible:

questions.question: I am intending to study a Postgraduate Certificate, Diploma or a PGCE and have previously graduated with a Bachelor's degree from the University of Bristol. Am I eligible for the discount?
questions.answer: No, you would not be eligible for the discount on your programme.
