You would be eligible for the discount on any future course that does meet the requirement of progressing to a higher level of study, as well all registration and fee requirements. This page has details of these requirements.

questions.question: I am intending to study a Taught Master’s and have previously completed a Postgraduate Certificate, Diploma or PGCE. I haven’t studied at the University of Bristol before my Postgraduate Certificate, am I eligible for the discount on my MSc?
questions.answer: No, you would not be eligible for the discount on any course you intend to study in your current circumstances. Should you choose to study at the University of Bristol and complete your Taught Master’s, then you would be eligible for the discount on any future course that does meet the requirement of progressing to a higher level of study, as well as all registration and fee requirements. This page has details of these requirements.

questions.question: I graduated with my Bachelor's degree from the University of Bristol and have since completed a Postgraduate Certificate, Diploma or PGCE. I'm now looking at applying to a taught Master's degree. Am I eligible for the alumni discount?
questions.answer: Completing a Bachelor’s degree at the University of Bristol would mean that your Taught Master’s degree fees qualify for the discount, providing you meet all other criteria. This page has details of these requirements.

questions.question: I’ve completed a taught master’s at the University of Bristol and I’m going to study a PhD at the University of Bristol. Am I eligible for the alumni discount?
questions.answer: Completing a taught master’s degree at the University of Bristol would mean that your PhD degree fees qualify for the discount, providing you meet all other criteria. This page has details of these requirements.

questions.question: I’ve completed a Master’s by Research at the University of Bristol and I would like to go on to study a PhD at the University. Am I eligible for the alumni discount?
questions.answer: No, because you are not progressing to a higher-level qualification than you already hold. A Master’s by Research is a research programme and research to research is not classified as progression.

questions.question: I’m starting a PhD but I still need to complete my master’s dissertation in the first term. Am I eligible for the discount and will it be applied retrospectively?
questions.answer: We will require evidence that you have successfully completed your master’s at Bristol. Once this is obtained the discount will be applied. If you have already paid in full, you will receive a refund for the discounted amount.

questions.question: I’ve completed a PhD at the University of Bristol, and I would now like to study a master’s in another area at the university. Am I eligible for the alumni discount?
questions.answer: The Alumni Discount is only eligible for those progressing to a higher-level degree. Therefore, the discount would not be applicable in this case.

questions.question: I’m an Intercalating student. Would I be eligible for the discount?
questions.answer: You are not yet technically an Alumni as you have not yet graduated from your main programme of study. Therefore, you are not eligible.

questions.question: I graduated from UWE and studied the BEng Robotics undergraduate programme. Am I eligible?
questions.answer: You have not graduated from the University of Bristol and are therefore not eligible.

questions.question: When will I see the discount applied to my tuition fees in my financial statement?
questions.answer: You may not see your discount in your financial statement straight away. Your discount will need to be applied and processed. You will need to have fully registered for your course (not just registered online or provisionally registered) before the discount can be applied. This can then take a few days. If the discount has not appeared after 14 days, contact education-administration-office@bristol.ac.uk .

questions.question: Is the discount applied before or after sponsorship/bursary?
questions.answer: The discount will be applied to the self-funded balance that you as a student must pay after any sponsorship or bursary.

questions.question: I have two student numbers. What process should I follow to get the discount applied?
questions.answer: If you have two student numbers, contact education-administration-office@bristol.ac.uk and provide all student numbers you have been assigned. We will then manually assess your eligibility and confirm whether the discount will be applied.

questions.question: Who can apply for University of Bristol international postgraduate scholarships, and which programmes are eligible?
questions.answer: To be eligible for the University's postgraduate scholarships, you must:

questions.question: Do I need to have applied for a programme of study at the University of Bristol before I apply for the University of Bristol international postgraduate scholarships?
questions.answer: Yes. You need to have already applied to study at the University of Bristol starting in 2025 to apply for the University of Bristol international postgraduate scholarships.

questions.question: Do I need to have an offer to study at the University of Bristol to be able to apply for the University of Bristol international postgraduate scholarships?
questions.answer: No. As long as you meet the eligibility requirements and you have submitted an application to study at the University of Bristol, you can apply for the University of Bristol international postgraduate scholarships. This applies even if you have not yet received an offer to study.

questions.question: I am applying for more than one programme at the University of Bristol. How should I complete the international scholarships application form?
questions.answer: If you have applied to study more than one programme at the University of Bristol, you will be able to select multiple programmes on your application form.

questions.question: What documents do I need to apply for the University of Bristol international postgraduate scholarships?
questions.answer: You do not need to submit any documentation when applying for the University of Bristol international postgraduate scholarships.

questions.question: What is a student ID?
questions.answer: This is the number you received when you made an application to study at the University of Bristol.

questions.question: Is there an age restriction for applying for the University of Bristol international postgraduate scholarships?
questions.answer: No. There is no age restriction for students applying for the University of Bristol international postgraduate scholarships.

questions.question: Can my deposit deadline be extended if I’m applying for a scholarship?
questions.answer: Part-funded scholarships (including Think Big, Think Big Career Accelerator and GREAT) are not eligible for deposit deadline extensions.

questions.question: If I have applied to study a PhD programme, am I able to apply for the University of Bristol international postgraduate scholarships?
questions.answer: No. Unfortunately, the University of Bristol international postgraduate scholarships are only available for eligible postgraduate taught master's programmes.

questions.question: If I have applied to study a PGCE programme, am I able to apply for the University of Bristol international postgraduate scholarships?
questions.answer: No. Unfortunately, the University of Bristol international postgraduate scholarships are only available for eligible postgraduate taught master's programmes.

questions.question: If I have applied for more than one University scholarship, can I still I apply for the University of Bristol international postgraduate scholarships?
questions.answer: By completing the application form, you will be considered for all scholarships and bursaries for which you are eligible.

questions.question: Do the University of Bristol international postgraduate scholarships cover living expenses or air fare?
questions.answer: All University of Bristol international postgraduate scholarships are towards tuition fees only and will not cover any living expenses, air fare, or other expenses.

questions.question: Do I need to meet any extra English language requirements to be able to apply for the University of Bristol international postgraduate scholarships?
questions.answer: No. You will not need to meet any extra English language requirements to apply for the University of Bristol international postgraduate scholarships.

questions.question: Will I receive individual feedback on my application if I am unsuccessful?
questions.answer: No. Unfortunately, due to the large number of applications we receive, we are unable to provide individual feedback to applicants.

questions.question: Will a list of successful applicants be published on the University's website?
questions.answer: No. We will contact all applicants directly by email. We do not publish the total number of allocated awards.

questions.question: Can the University give me an early decision?
questions.answer: No. The University must follow the correct procedure to make sure that all applicants are considered fairly. Outcomes will be shared according to the timeline on our international scholarships webpage.

questions.answer: Students taking PGCE courses at University of Bristol may be eligible for the bursary.

questions.question: Which subject do you have to teach to receive the PGCE bursary or scholarship?
questions.answer: PGCE students studying at Bristol, who are training to teach any of the following subjects, are eligible for a bursary:

questions.question: I'd like to teach Italian but that is not listed. Can I still get a bursary?
questions.answer: The government funded bursaries and scholarships are available to students training to teach German, French or Spanish. The Modern Foreign Languages PGCE at University of Bristol mainly offers places to students who will teach combinations of those languages.

questions.question: Can EU/International students receive the bursary or scholarship?
questions.answer: All EU nationals who are deemed home students for fee purposes, and are eligible for student funding, should be entitled to a tax-free bursary or scholarship and a tuition fee loan. Under current rules, EU nationals can access this support if they have resided in the European Economic Area or Switzerland for three years before the start of the course.

questions.question: In addition to the PGCE bursary or scholarship, can I apply for a student loan?
questions.answer: Yes, many PGCE students will be eligible for a loan for tuition fees and a maintenance loan to support them while they are taking a PGCE.

questions.question: How do I apply for a student loan?
questions.answer: Funding for students from Wales and Northern Ireland is also available from the relevant funding provider. Visit Student Finance Wales and Student Finance NI for more information.

questions.question: How much will I have to pay back?
questions.answer: Student loans for PGCE students are the same as the undergraduate loans. While the total amount you are borrowing will increase, taking out these loans will not affect your repayment amounts. These are linked to your salary once you start earning above the income threshold. Information on current thresholds is available on the government's website.

questions.question: I am thinking of taking a PGCE via the SCITTGiTEProute. If I do this, how does it affect the funding?
questions.answer: School centred initial teacher training (SCITT) is offered by the University of Bristol via GiTEP in addition to the traditional University based PGCE route. Students taking either route are eligible for the same funding.

questions.question: Can PGCE students apply for a postgraduate master's loan from the Student Loans Company?
questions.answer: No, PGCE students are not eligible to apply for the government's postgraduate loan scheme which is only available for students taking a master's qualification. PGCE students wishing to take a student loan are eligible for the same loans as undergraduate students.

questions.question: If I receive the PGCE bursary or scholarship and later decide to study for a master's, can I apply for the postgraduate master's loan then?
questions.answer: Yes, this is possible but due to the current ELQ (Equivalent or Lower Qualification) rules if you take a PGCE and earn 60 credits towards a master's qualification it is not possible to use the credits towards a master's and take out a postgraduate master's loan.

questions.question: How do I know if I am eligible for a bursary?
questions.answer: Home UK students on undergraduate programmes, who receive a government maintenance (or special support) grant and whose household income is £50,000 or below will be eligible for a University of Bristol Bursary.

questions.question: How much is it worth?
questions.answer: A range of bursary amounts will apply between these qualifying household income levels for 2025/26, as shown in this table:

questions.question: Is there a deadline date to claim my University of Bristol Bursary?
questions.answer: Yes. You must have claimed your University of Bristol Bursary by the last day of the summer term for each academic year.

questions.question: How do I get means tested, so you know my household income?
questions.answer: You need to apply to your regional Student Finance provider and request to be assessed for means-tested student finance. They will ask you for details of your household income and check the figures provided by your parents/sponsors. You are automatically opted in to allowing your Student Finance provider to share your household income with us.

questions.question: Who is my regional Student Finance provider?
questions.answer: That will depend on where you normally live when not at University.

questions.question: Do I need to complete a separate application form to apply for the bursary?
questions.answer: No. Your regional provider will assess your entitlement to means tested support using details of your household income provided on your application for student funding. They will pass this information to the Student Loans Company.

questions.question: Do I need to give my consent to share this information?
questions.answer: Yes. However, you are automatically opted in when you apply for government funding.

questions.question: I originally opted out of giving my consent (or my parents/sponsors did), is it too late to give consent now?
questions.answer: No, it isn't too late, but you and your parent/sponsor must call the appropriate number. Consent can be given at any time during the year.

questions.question: What will happen once the University of Bristol receives details of my household income from the Student Loans Company?
questions.answer: You will be emailed as soon as possible in the first few weeks of term to confirm your bursary award. Your notification of award will be delayed if you were late:

questions.question: Can I provide my household income through other means?
questions.answer: No, we can only accept this information via your student finance provider.

questions.question: I don’t want to take out a government loan, can I still get the bursary?
questions.answer: Even if you don't want to take out a loan, we require that you are means-tested by your Regional Funding Provider. To do this, you must apply for a loan as normal and then request that the amount is changed to £0.

questions.question: How will the bursary be paid?
questions.answer: The bursary will be paid directly into your bank account by BACS payment.

questions.question: How do I give the University of Bristol my bank details?
questions.answer: Once you have arrived and registered with the University, you will need to supply your bank account details in eVision .

questions.question: When will I receive payment of my University of Bristol Bursary?
questions.answer: The bursary will be paid in three instalments provided you are still registered on your course at the time of payment.

questions.question: I am studying medicine/dentistry. If I decide to intercalate as part of my programme, how will my bursary entitlement be affected?
questions.answer: If you decide to intercalate, your NHS funding will start earlier in your programme. This means your University of Bristol bursary entitlement will also stop earlier.

questions.question: If my household income is less than £50,000 and I only give my consent to share part way through the academic year, will this affect payment of my University of Bristol Bursary?
questions.answer: If we receive your household information before the last day of the academic year, you shall receive the bursary and be back-paid any payments you may have missed that academic year. Payments from previous academic years will not be back-paid.

questions.question: My first year is about to start and I have not yet applied for statutory support from my regional provider. How can I find out if I might qualify for a means-tested support, and is it too late to apply?
questions.answer: You can apply for statutory support up to nine months after the start of your academic year in England, Wales and Northern Ireland.

questions.question: Will a late application to my Regional Funding Provider for statutory support affect my entitlement for a bursary from the University of Bristol?
questions.answer: No. Provided your household income is £50,000 or less and you give your consent for the Student Loans Company to share this information, the University of Bristol will still pay you a bursary. However, your payments will be delayed, so apply as soon as you can.

questions.question: What happens if I supply you with the incorrect bank details?
questions.answer: Make sure that you supply an accurate bank account number and sort code in the first instance. If you supply incorrect bank details or change banks without updating us, your bursary payment will fail.

questions.question: Can I receive my bursary earlier?
questions.answer: No, we cannot expedite bursary payments. If you are concerned about financing your studies, please have a look at our money advice web page .

questions.question: I’m receiving the maximum government loan, why am I not receiving the maximum bursary?
questions.answer: The maintenance loan bands and our award bands are different. Either may be changed independently from the other.

questions.question: Why is my award less than I expected?
questions.answer: Your award may be less than you expected because:

questions.question: Why are you doing this research?
questions.answer: We want to help people with mild cognitive impairment. We don’t yet know the best way to show and measure the usefulness of a new treatment or way of supporting someone with mild cognitive impairment. We would like to create a list of things that people agree are important to collect and measure in research that aims to help people with mild cognitive impairment.

questions.question: Do I have to join in?
questions.answer: No, you do not have to join in. Please feel free to talk to your family or friends about the research to help you decide. If you say no, you will continue to receive the same healthcare for your mild cognitive impairment. If you say yes, you can change your mind later. You can drop out at any time.

questions.question: What will it involve?
questions.answer: If you say yes, we will start by asking when you were diagnosed with mild cognitive impairment and if anything has changed since your diagnosis .

questions.question: Do I need someone to be with me or help me during the surveys and/or interview?
questions.answer: No. You can complete the study without a ‘study partner’. If you would like someone to sit with you whilst you complete the study tasks, they can.

questions.question: What are the good things about being on the study?
questions.answer: The research will help us to improve research and healthcare to better support and treat people with mild cognitive impairment.

questions.question: What are the bad things about joining in?
questions.answer: Taking part will take up some of your time.

questions.question: Will you tell my GP I’m involved in the study?
questions.answer: At the start of the study, we will ask if you think there has been any changes to your thinking and memory since your diagnosis. If you think things have become more difficult, we will ask if you would like us to contact your GP about your symptoms.

questions.question: How will we use information about you?
questions.answer: We will need to use information from you and your medical records for this research project.

questions.question: What are your choices about how your information is used?
questions.answer: You can find out more about how we use your information:

questions.question: Where can you find out more about how your information is used?
questions.answer: You can find out more about how we use your information:

questions.question: What if something goes wrong or I want to complain?
questions.answer: If you wish to complain about the study, please contact the research team (details at the end of this information sheet) or the Sponsor of the study, University of Bristol, by emailing research-governance@bristol.ac.uk or by calling 0117 428 3065.

questions.question: What should I do now?
questions.answer: If you would like to ask a question or think you would like to take part, please contact the research team:

questions.question: 1. Do I have to share everyday?
questions.answer: No, the University of Bristol Car Sharing scheme enables you to choose the days that you want to share.

questions.question: 2. What if I car share and have to leave work suddenly?
questions.answer: You need to advise your car share partner as soon as possible so they can make alternative arrangements.  The University offers a guaranteed ride home scheme in emergency / unforeseen circumstances only and this is available to all registered car-sharers. If you need to travel home and do not have your car available, Security Services (0117 92) 87848 will arrange for a taxi to take you home and will settle the account for you. Rules governing the Transport Plan apply. This is only applicable to formal University car sharing team members.

questions.question: 3. What happens if I am the driver and am sick?
questions.answer: You must contact your car share partner(s) as soon as possible so that they can make alternative arrangements. As a passenger it is also essential for you to let the driver know you are ill so that they know not to wait if you are not at your pick up point.

questions.question: 4. I work shifts. Can I still share?
questions.answer: Yes, car sharing is flexible. If you work irregular hours, you can use the University of Bristol Car Sharing Scheme to identify car share partners who work similar hours to you.

questions.question: 5. I only have use of the car occasionally. Can I still share?
questions.answer: Yes, the system will match you on appropriate days.

questions.question: 6. What about sharing costs?
questions.answer: There are various ways in which this can be done:

questions.question: 7. What are the insurance implications of car sharing?
questions.answer: You must be fully insured and it is advisable to inform your insurance company that you are registered in a car share scheme. This should not incur additional costs. Most insurance policies cover you to carry passengers on your journey to work, as long as you don't charge your passengers more than the running costs of the vehicle.

questions.question: 8. How safe is it to use the University of Bristol Car Sharing Scheme?
questions.answer: All members’ details are stored securely in the database and works on the principle of anonymously brokering matches. The system will identify possible car share matches and then users will select which match(es) they would like to pursue. At this stage the system will forward the details of the possible match to the individual(s) concerned (via email). This puts the users in control of the information exchange – personal information will only be exchanged if both parties request it. Once both users have approved and exchanged details in this way, this will be considered a brokered match.

questions.question: 9. I’m a woman and would like to car share but would only want to share with another female. Is this possible?
questions.answer: Yes, the University of Bristol Car Sharing Scheme has a matching facility so that you can specify same-sex matches i.e. females only.

questions.question: 10. What happens if I find that car sharing doesn't suit me?
questions.answer: If you find that car sharing does not suit you, you can stop at any time.

questions.question: Where will I take my dog?
questions.answer: All work with your dog will be carried out at the Bristol Veterinary School by the team of specialists using state of the art care and facilities at Langford Vets . Langford Vets is a wholly owned subsidiary of the University of Bristol which provides clinical veterinary care.
